statement:
Let $P$ be a poset of height $h$. Then $P$ can be partitioned into $h$
antichains and furthermore at least $h$ antichains are required.

Induction on $h$. If $h=1$, then no elements of $P$ are comparable, so
$P$ is an antichain. Now suppose that $P$ has height $h\geq 2$ and that
the theorem is true for $h-1$. Let $A_1$ be the set of maximal elements
of $P$. Then $A_1$ is an antichain in $P$ and $P-A_1$ has height $h-1$
since we have removed precisely one element from every chain. Hence,
$P-A_1$ can be paritioned into $h-1$ antichains $A_2,A_3,\dots A_h$. Now
we have the partition $A_1\cup A_2\cup\dots\cup A_h$ of $P$ into $h$
antichains as desired.

The necessity of $h$ antichains is trivial by the pigeonhole principle;
since $P$ has height $h$, it has a chain of length $h$, and each element
of this chain must be placed in a different antichain of our partition.
